canonical_explanation.text: A globe is a small model of the Earth that shows its round (spherical) shape. It shows how the continents and oceans are arranged on the Earth's surface. A map is a flat drawing of the Earth's surface or a part of it. While a globe shows the whole Earth, a map can show the whole world, a country, a city, or even a neighbourhood. There are seven continents: Asia (largest), Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia (smallest). There are five oceans: Pacific (largest), Atlantic, Indian, Southern (Antarctic), and Arctic (smallest). Latitude lines run horizontally around the Earth. The Equator is the most important latitude line at 0 degrees, dividing the Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. Longitude lines run vertically from the North Pole to the South Pole. The Prime Meridian is at 0 degrees longitude. The four main directions are North, South, East, and West. Maps use symbols and colours to represent features: blue for water, green for forests/low land, and brown for mountains/hills. A map scale helps us understand the relationship between distance on a map and actual distance on the ground.
rules: Globe: a small model of the Earth showing its spherical shape
Map: a flat drawing of the Earth's surface or part of it
Seven continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia
Five oceans: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern (Antarctic), Arctic
Latitude: horizontal lines, Equator at 0 degrees divides Earth into North and South hemispheres
Longitude: vertical lines, Prime Meridian at 0 degrees
Four main directions: North (up), South (down), East (right), West (left) on a standard map
Map colours: blue = water, green = forests/lowland, brown = mountains, yellow = desert
Map scale: shows the ratio between map distance and real distance
India is in Asia, between the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal

questions.question_text: What is a globe?

options.text: A flat map of the world
A small, round model of the Earth

questions.explanation_correct: A globe is a small, round (spherical) model of the Earth. It shows the shape of the Earth, the location of continents and oceans, and how they are arranged. Unlike a flat map, a globe accurately represents the Earth's round shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe is a three-dimensional, round model of the Earth. A map is flat. A compass is a tool for finding direction. A photograph shows a picture. The globe is special because it shows the true shape of our planet.

questions.question_text: What shape is the Earth?
questions.explanation_correct: The Earth is roughly spherical, meaning it is round like a ball. It is not a perfect sphere; it is slightly flattened at the poles and bulges slightly at the equator. This is why a globe, which is round, is the best model of the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Earth is roughly spherical (round). Scientists and astronauts have confirmed this. A globe accurately represents this round shape. The Earth is not flat, cube-shaped, or cone-shaped.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between a globe and a map?

options.text: A globe is round and shows the Earth's true shape; a map is a flat drawing
A globe is flat and a map is round
Maps are always bigger than globes

questions.explanation_correct: A globe is a three-dimensional, round model that shows the Earth's true shape. A map is a flat, two-dimensional drawing. A globe is more accurate in showing shapes and sizes, but a map is easier to carry and can show more detail of a specific area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe is round (3D) and a map is flat (2D). Each has advantages: globes show the Earth's true shape and proportions, while maps are portable and can show detailed information about a specific area.

questions.question_text: A globe can show the true shape and size of continents more accurately than a flat map.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Since the Earth is round, a globe represents the continents and oceans more accurately than a flat map. When you flatten the round Earth into a map, some shapes and sizes get distorted (stretched or squished).
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. A globe shows the Earth as it really is. Flat maps always have some distortion because you cannot perfectly represent a round surface on a flat sheet. Globes maintain the correct shapes and proportions.

questions.question_text: Why would a pilot flying from India to the USA prefer to use a globe rather than a flat map to plan the route?

options.text: Because a globe shows the actual curved path (shortest distance) between two places
Because maps do not show the USA
Because flat maps are too heavy to carry

questions.explanation_correct: A globe shows the shortest route between two distant places more accurately because it represents the Earth's curved surface. On a flat map, the shortest path between India and the USA may look straight, but on a globe, the curved path over the Arctic region is actually shorter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe shows the real shortest path between places because the Earth is round. On flat maps, distances and routes can be misleading. For long-distance flights, understanding the curved surface of the Earth helps find the shortest route.

questions.question_text: A globe is tilted on its axis at about 23.5 degrees. This tilt causes:
questions.explanation_correct: The Earth's tilt of about 23.5 degrees causes the seasons. As the Earth orbits the Sun, different parts receive more or less sunlight due to this tilt. When the Northern Hemisphere is tilted towards the Sun, it is summer there and winter in the Southern Hemisphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Earth's tilt causes seasons. Day and night are caused by the Earth's rotation (spinning). Earthquakes are caused by movements in the Earth's crust. Rain is caused by the water cycle. The tilt determines which parts of the Earth get more sunlight.

questions.question_text: How many continents are there in the world?
questions.explanation_correct: There are 7 continents in the world: Asia (largest), Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia/Oceania (smallest). India is located in the continent of Asia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 7 continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia. Do not confuse continents with oceans (there are 5 oceans). Asia is the largest continent, and Australia is the smallest.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest continent in the world?
questions.explanation_correct: Asia is the largest continent in the world. It covers about 30% of the total land area and is home to more than 60% of the world's population. India, China, Japan, and many other countries are in Asia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asia is the largest continent both in area and population. Africa is the second largest. Europe is much smaller. India is in Asia. Asia stretches from the Middle East to Japan and from Russia to Indonesia.

questions.question_text: How many oceans are there in the world?
questions.explanation_correct: There are 5 oceans in the world: Pacific Ocean (largest), Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Southern (Antarctic) Ocean, and Arctic Ocean (smallest). Oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are 5 oceans: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern, and Arctic. The Pacific Ocean is the largest and the Arctic is the smallest. There are 7 continents but only 5 oceans. Oceans cover most of the Earth's surface.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest ocean in the world?
questions.explanation_correct: The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean, covering about one-third of the Earth's surface. It is bigger than all the land on Earth combined. It stretches from Asia and Australia in the west to North and South America in the east.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Pacific Ocean is the largest. The order by size is: Pacific (largest), Atlantic, Indian, Southern, Arctic (smallest). The Pacific Ocean is so large that it covers more area than all the land on Earth put together.

questions.question_text: India is located in which continent?
questions.explanation_correct: India is located in Asia, specifically in the South Asian subcontinent. Asia is the largest continent. India is surrounded by the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is in Asia. All of India's neighbours (Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Sri Lanka) are also in Asia. India is in the southern part of Asia, called South Asia.

questions.question_text: Antarctica is the coldest continent and is covered almost entirely by ice.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Antarctica is the coldest, driest, and windiest continent. It is located at the South Pole and is almost entirely covered by ice. No country owns Antarctica, and it has no permanent human residents, only research stations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Antarctica is at the South Pole and is covered by a thick ice sheet. Temperatures can drop below -80°C. Scientists from many countries, including India, have research stations there.

questions.question_text: Which ocean lies between India and Africa?
questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Ocean lies between India and Africa. India is on the eastern side and Africa on the western side of the Indian Ocean. The Indian Ocean is the third largest ocean and is named after India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indian Ocean separates India from Africa. The Atlantic Ocean separates Africa from the Americas. The Pacific separates Asia from the Americas. The Arctic is at the North Pole.

questions.question_text: Which continent is known as the 'Dark Continent'?
questions.explanation_correct: Africa was historically called the 'Dark Continent' by European explorers because much of it was unexplored and unknown to them. Africa is the second largest continent, known for the Sahara Desert, River Nile, and incredible wildlife.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Africa was called the Dark Continent because Europeans had little knowledge about its interior. Today, Africa is well-explored and is the second largest continent. It is home to the Sahara Desert (the world's largest hot desert) and the Nile (the longest river).

questions.question_text: Which pair is correctly matched: continent and a country in it?
questions.explanation_correct: Egypt is in Africa (northeast Africa). Brazil is in South America, not Asia. India is in Asia, not Europe. Australia is its own continent, not in North America. Egypt is famous for the pyramids and the Nile River.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct match is Africa - Egypt. Brazil is in South America. India is in Asia. Australia is its own continent (Oceania). Remembering which countries are in which continents is an important geography skill.

questions.question_text: What is the Equator?

options.text: A vertical line on the globe
An imaginary horizontal line at 0 degrees latitude that divides the Earth into two halves
A real line drawn on the Earth's surface

questions.explanation_correct: The Equator is an imaginary horizontal line at 0 degrees latitude. It divides the Earth into two equal halves: the Northern Hemisphere (above the Equator) and the Southern Hemisphere (below the Equator). Places near the Equator are generally hot.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Equator is an imaginary horizontal line at 0 degrees latitude. It is not a real line that you can see. It divides the Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The Equator is the widest part of the Earth.

questions.question_text: Latitude lines run:

options.text: From the North Pole to the South Pole (vertically)
In circles around the poles only

questions.explanation_correct: Latitude lines (also called parallels) run from east to west (horizontally) around the Earth. The Equator is the most important latitude line at 0 degrees. Latitude measures how far north or south a place is from the Equator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Latitude lines run horizontally (east to west). Longitude lines run vertically (north to south). A simple way to remember: latitude lines are like the rungs of a ladder (horizontal), and 'lat' rhymes with 'flat'.

questions.question_text: Longitude lines run:

options.text: From the North Pole to the South Pole (vertically)

questions.explanation_correct: Longitude lines (also called meridians) run from the North Pole to the South Pole (vertically). The Prime Meridian at 0 degrees longitude passes through Greenwich, London. Longitude measures how far east or west a place is from the Prime Meridian.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Longitude lines run vertically from pole to pole. Latitude lines run horizontally. The Prime Meridian (0 degrees longitude) divides the Earth into the Eastern and Western Hemispheres.

questions.question_text: The Prime Meridian is at:
questions.explanation_correct: The Prime Meridian is at 0 degrees longitude. It passes through Greenwich, London, England. It divides the Earth into the Eastern Hemisphere and Western Hemisphere. The Equator (0 degrees latitude) is the horizontal dividing line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Prime Meridian is at 0 degrees longitude (vertical). The Equator is at 0 degrees latitude (horizontal). The Prime Meridian runs through Greenwich, England, and divides the Earth into Eastern and Western Hemispheres.

questions.question_text: The Equator divides the Earth into the Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Equator (0 degrees latitude) divides the Earth into the Northern Hemisphere (north of the Equator) and the Southern Hemisphere (south of the Equator). India is in the Northern Hemisphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The Equator divides the Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. India, most of Asia, Europe, and North America are in the Northern Hemisphere. Australia, most of South America, and Antarctica are in the Southern Hemisphere.

questions.question_text: India is located in which hemisphere(s)?
questions.explanation_correct: India is in the Northern Hemisphere (north of the Equator) and the Eastern Hemisphere (east of the Prime Meridian). India lies between latitudes 8°N and 37°N and longitudes 68°E and 97°E.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is in the Northern Hemisphere (above the Equator) and the Eastern Hemisphere (east of the Prime Meridian at Greenwich). Countries like Brazil and Australia are in the Southern Hemisphere.

questions.question_text: What would happen to the climate if a place is very close to the Equator?

options.text: It would be hot and receive a lot of sunlight throughout the year
It would have snow all year

questions.explanation_correct: Places near the Equator receive direct sunlight throughout the year, making them hot. Countries like Kenya, Singapore, and parts of South India near the Equator have warm weather all year round. The sun's rays are strongest at the Equator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Places near the Equator are hot because they receive the most direct sunlight. As you move away from the Equator towards the poles, the climate gets cooler. The Equator gets the strongest sunlight because the sun is almost directly overhead.

questions.question_text: On a map, blue colour usually represents:
questions.explanation_correct: On maps, blue colour is used to represent water bodies such as rivers, lakes, seas, and oceans. This is a standard convention used by mapmakers around the world. The deeper the blue, the deeper the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blue represents water on maps. Green represents forests and lowlands, brown represents mountains and highlands, and yellow/sandy colour represents deserts. These colours help us quickly identify features on a map.

questions.question_text: What are the four main (cardinal) directions?
questions.explanation_correct: The four main (cardinal) directions are North, South, East, and West. On a standard map, North is at the top, South at the bottom, East on the right, and West on the left. You can remember them using 'Never Eat Shredded Wheat' (clockwise from North).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The four cardinal directions are North, South, East, and West. On maps, North is always at the top. The intermediate directions are Northeast, Southeast, Southwest, and Northwest.

questions.question_text: On a standard map, North is at the:
questions.explanation_correct: On a standard map, North is always at the top. South is at the bottom, East is on the right, and West is on the left. Most maps have a compass rose or arrow showing the direction of North.
questions.explanation_incorrect: North is at the top of a standard map. Most maps follow this convention. A compass rose on the map shows the direction of North. If North is at the top, then South is at the bottom, East is right, and West is left.

questions.question_text: What does a map scale tell us?

options.text: The relationship between distance on the map and actual distance on the ground
The date the map was made

questions.explanation_correct: A map scale shows the relationship between the distance shown on the map and the actual distance on the ground. For example, if the scale says 1 cm = 10 km, then 1 centimetre on the map represents 10 kilometres in real life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The map scale tells us how much real-world distance is represented by a given distance on the map. Without a scale, we could not determine actual distances between places. The scale makes maps useful for measuring real distances.

questions.question_text: On a map, green colour usually represents forests and lowlands.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. On maps, green colour is used to represent forests, grasslands, and lowlands. Different shades of green may be used: darker green for dense forests and lighter green for grasslands. This is a standard map colour convention.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Green represents vegetation and lowlands on maps. Blue represents water, brown represents mountains and highlands, and yellow/tan represents deserts. These standard colours help us read maps quickly.

questions.question_text: On a map with a scale of 1 cm = 50 km, if two cities are 3 cm apart on the map, what is the real distance between them?
questions.explanation_correct: If 1 cm on the map represents 50 km in real life, then 3 cm represents 3 x 50 = 150 km. Map scales help us calculate actual distances between places. This is one of the most useful features of a map.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the scale: 3 cm on the map x 50 km per cm = 150 km actual distance. The map scale helps us convert map distances to real distances. Without the scale, we could not know the actual distance between places.

questions.question_text: Brown colour on a map usually represents:
questions.explanation_correct: Brown colour on maps represents mountains, hills, and highlands. The darker the brown, the higher the elevation. This colour convention helps us identify mountainous regions like the Himalayas, Western Ghats, and Eastern Ghats on a map.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brown represents mountains and highlands. Blue is for water, green is for forests and lowlands, and cities are usually shown with dots or special symbols. The brown colour helps us spot mountainous areas easily on any map.

questions.question_text: A compass rose on a map shows:
questions.explanation_correct: A compass rose on a map shows the directions: North, South, East, and West (and sometimes the intermediate directions). It helps the map reader orient themselves and understand which way features on the map are facing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The compass rose shows directions on a map. The scale shows distances, the title tells what the map is about, and the legend/key explains the symbols. The compass rose is usually a star-shaped symbol with N, S, E, W marked.

questions.question_text: A political map shows:

options.text: Country boundaries, states, and capital cities

questions.explanation_correct: A political map shows the boundaries of countries and states, capital cities, and major cities. It uses different colours for different countries or states. A physical map, on the other hand, shows natural features like mountains and rivers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Political maps show human-made boundaries: country borders, states, and cities. Physical maps show natural features like mountains and rivers. Road maps show highways. Climate maps show weather patterns. Each type of map serves a different purpose.

questions.question_text: A physical map shows:

options.text: Natural features like mountains, rivers, plains, and deserts

questions.explanation_correct: A physical map shows natural features of the Earth such as mountains, rivers, plains, plateaus, deserts, and oceans. It uses different colours and shading to show elevation (height above sea level) and terrain types.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Physical maps show natural features of the land: mountains (brown), rivers (blue), forests (green), deserts (yellow), and plains. Country boundaries and cities are shown on political maps.

questions.question_text: Sita wants to find out which states border her state, Madhya Pradesh. Which type of map should she use?
questions.explanation_correct: Sita should use a political map because it shows state and country boundaries. A political map of India will clearly show all the states neighbouring Madhya Pradesh: Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Rajasthan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A political map shows boundaries of states and countries. A physical map shows natural features, a climate map shows weather patterns, and a road map shows highways. To find neighbouring states, a political map is the best choice.

questions.question_text: Ravi wants to find the mountain ranges in India. Which type of map should he look at?
questions.explanation_correct: Ravi should use a physical map because it shows natural features like mountains, rivers, plains, and deserts. The Himalayas, Western Ghats, Eastern Ghats, and Aravalli Range would all be shown on a physical map of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A physical map shows natural features including mountains. Political maps show boundaries and cities. Road maps show transportation routes. Population maps show where people live. For mountains, rivers, and terrain, use a physical map.

questions.question_text: You can use any type of map for any purpose because all maps show the same information.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Different types of maps show different information. Political maps show boundaries and cities, physical maps show terrain and natural features, road maps show transportation routes, and climate maps show weather. You need to choose the right type of map for your purpose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. Maps are made for specific purposes. A political map would not help you find mountains, and a physical map would not help you find state boundaries. Choosing the right map type is important for finding the information you need.

questions.question_text: The legend or key on a map helps us to:

options.text: Understand what the symbols and colours on the map mean
Find the date of the map

questions.explanation_correct: The legend (or key) on a map explains what the different symbols, colours, and lines on the map represent. For example, it tells you that a blue line means a river, a black dot means a city, or a star means a capital city.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The legend/key explains symbols and colours. The compass rose shows directions. The scale helps calculate distance. The legend is like a dictionary for the map, helping you understand all the symbols used.

questions.question_text: The smallest continent in the world is _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Australia is the smallest continent in the world. It is also the only continent that is a single country. It is surrounded by the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. Australia is in the Southern Hemisphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Australia is the smallest continent. The order from largest to smallest is: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia. Despite being the smallest continent, Australia is still a large country.

questions.question_text: A place has a latitude of 0 degrees. This means the place is located on the:
questions.explanation_correct: 0 degrees latitude is the Equator. The North Pole is at 90 degrees north latitude, and the South Pole is at 90 degrees south latitude. The Prime Meridian is at 0 degrees longitude, not latitude.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0 degrees latitude is the Equator, the imaginary line dividing the Earth into Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The North Pole is 90°N, the South Pole is 90°S, and the Prime Meridian is 0° longitude (not latitude).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of a map over a globe?

options.text: A map shows the true shape of the Earth
A map can be folded, carried easily, and can show detailed information about a small area
A map is always more accurate than a globe
A map can spin like a globe

questions.explanation_correct: Maps have several advantages over globes: they can be folded and carried easily, they can show details of a small area (like a city or neighbourhood), and different types of maps can show different information. A globe is better for showing the Earth's true shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maps are portable and can show detailed information about specific areas. Globes are better for showing the Earth's true shape. Maps and globes complement each other: use globes for understanding the whole Earth and maps for detailed information about specific places.

questions.question_text: If you face North, East would be on your:
questions.explanation_correct: If you face North, East is on your right side. West is on your left, and South is behind you. This is a useful way to understand directions in real life and on maps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When facing North: East is on your right, West is on your left, and South is behind you. On a standard map, this is the same: North (top), East (right), South (bottom), West (left).

questions.question_text: Which ocean is the smallest?
questions.explanation_correct: The Arctic Ocean is the smallest and shallowest of the five oceans. It is located around the North Pole and is mostly covered by ice. The order from largest to smallest is: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern, Arctic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Arctic Ocean is the smallest. It surrounds the North Pole and is mostly frozen. The Southern Ocean surrounds Antarctica. The Pacific is the largest ocean. Remember: Pacific > Atlantic > Indian > Southern > Arctic.

questions.question_text: Every map should have three essential components. Which of the following is NOT an essential component of a map?
questions.explanation_correct: The three essential components of a map are: title (what the map shows), scale (distance relationship), and compass rose/direction indicator (shows North). Photographs are not a necessary part of a map, although they may sometimes be included for reference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Every map needs a title, scale, and direction indicator (compass rose). These three elements make a map useful and accurate. Photographs are not required on maps, although some modern maps may include them.

questions.question_text: The Prime Meridian passes through _____, England.
questions.explanation_correct: The Prime Meridian (0 degrees longitude) passes through Greenwich, a place in London, England. This is why it is also called the Greenwich Meridian. The Royal Observatory in Greenwich is the reference point for the world's time zones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Prime Meridian passes through Greenwich, which is a borough in London. It is sometimes also called the Greenwich Meridian. Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) is based on this location and was historically the world's time standard.

questions.question_text: India is surrounded by three bodies of water. Which ones?

options.text: Pacific Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Arctic Ocean
Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, Indian Ocean
Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea, Indian Ocean
South China Sea, Arabian Sea, Pacific Ocean

questions.explanation_correct: India is surrounded by the Arabian Sea to the west, the Bay of Bengal to the east, and the Indian Ocean to the south. These three water bodies make India a peninsula (land surrounded by water on three sides).
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is bordered by the Arabian Sea (west), Bay of Bengal (east), and Indian Ocean (south). India is a peninsula because it is surrounded by water on three sides. The tip of India at Kanyakumari is where these three meet.

questions.question_text: A treasure map says: 'Walk 10 steps North, then 5 steps East, then 3 steps South.' If you follow these directions, you will end up _____ of your starting point.
questions.explanation_correct: If you walk 10 steps North and then 3 steps South, you end up 7 steps North of your starting point (10 - 3 = 7). You also walked 5 steps East. So you are 7 steps North and 5 steps East of where you started.
questions.explanation_incorrect: You need to add up all the movements: 10 North - 3 South = 7 North, and 5 East stays 5 East. So you end up 7 steps North and 5 steps East of your starting point. Understanding directions helps in reading maps and following instructions.

questions.question_text: The Earth is perfectly flat like a chapati.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The Earth is roughly spherical (round like a ball), not flat. This has been proven by photographs from space, satellite images, and centuries of scientific observation. A globe represents the Earth's true shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Earth is not flat. It is roughly spherical (round). Astronauts have photographed the Earth from space, confirming its round shape. A globe models this round shape, while a flat map is just a representation.

questions.question_text: If you are facing West, which direction is behind you?
questions.explanation_correct: If you are facing West, East is behind you. North would be on your right, and South would be on your left. Opposite directions are always: North-South and East-West.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When facing West, East is behind you (opposite direction). North is to your right and South to your left. The opposite pairs of directions are: North and South, East and West.

questions.question_text: The Tropic of Cancer passes through India. It is located at:
questions.explanation_correct: The Tropic of Cancer is at 23.5 degrees North latitude and passes through 8 states of India: Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, West Bengal, Tripura, and Mizoram. It divides India roughly into two halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Tropic of Cancer is at 23.5°N latitude. It passes through India dividing it into roughly equal halves. The Tropic of Capricorn (23.5°S) is in the Southern Hemisphere. The Equator is at 0°. The Arctic Circle is at 66.5°N.

questions.question_text: Which tool is used to find the direction of North?
questions.explanation_correct: A compass is used to find the direction of North. It has a magnetic needle that always points towards the Earth's magnetic North Pole. Travellers, hikers, and sailors use compasses to navigate and find their way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compass finds direction. A thermometer measures temperature. A ruler measures length. A clock tells time. The compass needle points North because it is attracted to the Earth's magnetic North Pole.

questions.question_text: Which continent is entirely in the Southern Hemisphere and is almost uninhabited?
questions.explanation_correct: Antarctica is entirely in the Southern Hemisphere, located around the South Pole. It is almost uninhabited, with only scientists living in research stations. It is the coldest, driest, and windiest continent, covered almost entirely by ice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antarctica is at the South Pole, entirely in the Southern Hemisphere, and has no permanent inhabitants. Australia is also mostly in the Southern Hemisphere but is well-populated. Africa and South America span both hemispheres.
